Georgetown netmen forced the
Black and Blue racqueters to bow
to them Monday. The match was
played on the Georgetown courts,
which were in very poor condition. Excepting for the roughness
of the court which naturally retards the speed of a match, the
contests were interesting and a
great deal of skill and strategic
play was in evidence.
Hoffmeister and Kunkle led off
with a beautiful singles match,
in which Hoffmeister was completely outclassed. It was the fastest play of the day; Kunkle exhibiting an unusually powerful
serve. Score 6-1, 6 1.

Homewood will be the battle
site tomorrow upon which the
Hopkins ball-tossers will strive to
overcome the Mount St. Mary
nine from Emmitsburg-.
With the second encounter with
the Loyola nine a thing of the
past, the team will have its mettle tested for the first time in a
game that has bearing on the state
championship.
Smarting from its defeat at the
hands of Mount St. Mary last
year, the Black and Blue team will
endeavor to gain vengeance. The
contest last year was a keen disappointment to the Hopkins rooters due to the fact that for six innings the opposing players' bats
were held in check while the Blue
Jays had taken the lead, 1 to 0, in
the first inning. From the sixth
inning on, however, it was a different story. Taking advantage of
the weakening of the Hopkins
slab men the opposing team piled
up a total of nine runs in the last
three innings.
A rally by the Homewooders
was productive of three additional
runs but the game ended with
Hopkins on the short end of a 9
to 4 count.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 9, 1924

A. S. C. E. TO ELECT NEW OFFICERS AT MEETING
TODAY
Election of new officers will occupy the attention of the members at the last meeting during
the scholastic year of the Hopkins Student Chapter of the
American Society of Civil Engineers, which will be held today
at.4:15 P. M.
The resigning officers are:
President, William North Crout ;
vice-president, C. Clayton Singleton; secretary, John Wysong, and
treasurer, Robert B. Burgess.
One of the most successful seasons since the installation of the
student chapter will be concluded
at this meeting. All the varying
phases of the wide field of civil
engineering have been covered, to
a greater or less extent, by the
engineers who have addressed the
chapter. One of the most important of these was Major Herman
F. Doelman, a well-known consulting engineer of Baltimore,
who spoke on "The Construction .of the Standard Oil Building." Other subjects covered by
local engineers include "The Engineering of Housing Development", "Construction of the Filtration Plant of Baltimore", and
"The Construction of the Loch
Raven Dam."
Plans for the forthcoming
scholastic year will be discussed
by the chapter immediately upon
the election of the new officers.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS.LETTER, MAY 9. 1924
PHI GAMS DEFEAT ALPHA
DELTS 22-8
Last Saturday morning on the
lower field, the hard-hitting Phi
Gamma Delta nine won their first
hold on the Inter-Fraternity baseball cup by defeating Alpha Delta
Phi. Fitz Dunning starred at the
plate, Stick in the box and Farinholt in the field for the Phi GainInas. Dunning knocked the only
home run in the game. For the
Alpha Delt's Fonda starred in the
box, Love at bat and Hiss in the
outfield. The Phi Gams got off
to an early lead—allowing only
one run in the first inning and
eleven in their first time

OMEGA BETA PI INITIATES
FIVE MEN
Omega Beta Pi held its initiation of Junior members on Friday evening, May 2, at the Silver
Arrow house. Five men were initiated: Spurier, Martin, Dunphy,
When
Houturick and Ginther.
Omega Beta Pi was founded at
the University of Illinois in 1914,
the main qualification for admission was scholarship, and the
fraternity remains true to this
policy. The object of the fraternity is to promote scholarship and
to raise the ideals and broaden
the outlook of pre-medical students who take courses leading to
an A. B. degree.
At the same time that undergraduates were initiated, four
faculty members who teach premedical subjects were made honorary members. They were: Dr.
Bliss, Professor of Physics; Dr.
Cowles, Professor of Biology; Dr.
Gilpin and Dr. Cartledge, Professors of Chemistry. The insignia
of honorary and graduate members is a gold key, which is identical in form with the undergraduate pin.
At the meeting, President Peyton announced that Dr. Kingsley,
a world famous authority on comparative anatomy, who is a professor at the University of Illinois
has been re-elected honorary president of the fraternity. He also
stated that during the Easter holidays a chapter at the University
of Texas had been formally initiated. This makes the total of
chapters now number six.
On May 15, a dinner and final
meeting will be held at the Hopkins Club. On this occasion officers for next year will be elected
and installed in office.

CHRISTIAN SERVICE CLUB
ELECTS OFFICERS
At a recent meeting of the
Christian Service Club, held at
the home of the retiring president, Paul Sylvester, elections of
the officers for the following year
were held. The results were:
President, Philip Pease, '25;
vice-president, Reno Harp, '26;
secretary, J. Wilson Hunter, '25;
treasurer, Robert L. Bull, '26.
The Club will continue its policy of practical work, through social services and charity organizations for the coming year.
Through the Hopkins Y. M. C.
A. it expects to play an important part in the Industrial Research Group to be held this. summer. The members, through actual work as, and with, manual
laborers, will try to obtain labor's point of view, so getting new
light on labor problems and conditions.

ACHIEVEMENT

in Electrification
of Industry
In 1891 the first electric motor was put to work in a
steel mill. In 1905 the first large rolling mill motor, and
in 1906,the first reversing mill motor were also installed
in steel mills. These motors—all Westinghouse Motors
—were history-makers in the steel industry.
Other industries too have profited by Westinghouse
engineering pioneering.
—In the textile industry, individual motor drive
became a reality in 1902, in the Sauguoit Silk Co.,
Philadelphia, Pa.
—In the rubber industry, Westinghouse ideas as
originally applied in 1900,are today the standard method
of application in plants throughout the world.
—In the handling of materials at the world's great
shipping centers, in the manufacturing of paper, in the
motion picture industry,in coal mining,in meat packing,
railroading, ship building—in fact, in every branch of
human activity can be found progress and profits
traceable directly to the pioneering of Westinghouse
Engineers.

Crackle! Crackle! Sparks leap higher
Up the chimney, out of sight.
Gathered here beside the fire,
Cozy in the hearthside light,
Let's be cheerful, let's be gay;
Bygone cares are fled away;
Let's forget turmoil of day,
Enjoying peaceful night.

Crackle softly! Dying embers
Cast a rose red cheering ray,
From the earth that slowly smoulders,
On life's happiness of gray.
We are tranquil, let us rest;
Balm that's brought at our behest
Salves our hearts, now richly blest,
By fireside time's short stay.

Homewood will be the battle
site tomorrow upon which the
Hopkins ball-tossers will strive to
overcome the Mount St. Mary
nine from Emmitsburg-.
With the second encounter with
the Loyola nine a thing of the
past, the team will have its mettle tested for the first time in a
game that has bearing on the state
championship.
Smarting from its defeat at the
hands of Mount St. Mary last
year, the Black and Blue team will
endeavor to gain vengeance. The
contest last year was a keen disappointment to the Hopkins rooters due to the fact that for six innings the opposing players' bats
were held in check while the Blue
Jays had taken the lead, 1 to 0, in
the first inning. From the sixth
inning on, however, it was a different story. Taking advantage of
the weakening of the Hopkins
slab men the opposing team piled
up a total of nine runs in the last
three innings.
A rally by the Homewooders
was productive of three additional
runs but the game ended with
Hopkins on the short end of a 9
to 4 count.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 9, 1924

A. S. C. E. TO ELECT NEW OFFICERS AT MEETING
TODAY
Election of new officers will occupy the attention of the members at the last meeting during
the scholastic year of the Hopkins Student Chapter of the
American Society of Civil Engineers, which will be held today
at.4:15 P. M.
The resigning officers are:
President, William North Crout ;
vice-president, C. Clayton Singleton; secretary, John Wysong, and
treasurer, Robert B. Burgess.
One of the most successful seasons since the installation of the
student chapter will be concluded
at this meeting. All the varying
phases of the wide field of civil
engineering have been covered, to
a greater or less extent, by the
engineers who have addressed the
chapter. One of the most important of these was Major Herman
F. Doelman, a well-known consulting engineer of Baltimore,
who spoke on "The Construction .of the Standard Oil Building." Other subjects covered by
local engineers include "The Engineering of Housing Development", "Construction of the Filtration Plant of Baltimore", and
"The Construction of the Loch
Raven Dam."
Plans for the forthcoming
scholastic year will be discussed
by the chapter immediately upon
the election of the new officers.

OMEGA BETA PI INITIATES
FIVE MEN
Omega Beta Pi held its initiation of Junior members on Friday evening, May 2, at the Silver
Arrow house. Five men were initiated: Spurier, Martin, Dunphy,
When
Houturick and Ginther.
Omega Beta Pi was founded at
the University of Illinois in 1914,
the main qualification for admission was scholarship, and the
fraternity remains true to this
policy. The object of the fraternity is to promote scholarship and
to raise the ideals and broaden
the outlook of pre-medical students who take courses leading to
an A. B. degree.
At the same time that undergraduates were initiated, four
faculty members who teach premedical subjects were made honorary members. They were: Dr.
Bliss, Professor of Physics; Dr.
Cowles, Professor of Biology; Dr.
Gilpin and Dr. Cartledge, Professors of Chemistry. The insignia
of honorary and graduate members is a gold key, which is identical in form with the undergraduate pin.
At the meeting, President Peyton announced that Dr. Kingsley,
a world famous authority on comparative anatomy, who is a professor at the University of Illinois
has been re-elected honorary president of the fraternity. He also
stated that during the Easter holidays a chapter at the University
of Texas had been formally initiated. This makes the total of
chapters now number six.
On May 15, a dinner and final
meeting will be held at the Hopkins Club. On this occasion officers for next year will be elected
and installed in office.

CHRISTIAN SERVICE CLUB
ELECTS OFFICERS
At a recent meeting of the
Christian Service Club, held at
the home of the retiring president, Paul Sylvester, elections of
the officers for the following year
were held. The results were:
President, Philip Pease, '25;
vice-president, Reno Harp, '26;
secretary, J. Wilson Hunter, '25;
treasurer, Robert L. Bull, '26.
The Club will continue its policy of practical work, through social services and charity organizations for the coming year.
Through the Hopkins Y. M. C.
A. it expects to play an important part in the Industrial Research Group to be held this. summer. The members, through actual work as, and with, manual
laborers, will try to obtain labor's point of view, so getting new
light on labor problems and conditions.

ACHIEVEMENT

in Electrification
of Industry
In 1891 the first electric motor was put to work in a
steel mill. In 1905 the first large rolling mill motor, and
in 1906,the first reversing mill motor were also installed
in steel mills. These motors—all Westinghouse Motors
—were history-makers in the steel industry.
Other industries too have profited by Westinghouse
engineering pioneering.
—In the textile industry, individual motor drive
became a reality in 1902, in the Sauguoit Silk Co.,
Philadelphia, Pa.
—In the rubber industry, Westinghouse ideas as
originally applied in 1900,are today the standard method
of application in plants throughout the world.
—In the handling of materials at the world's great
shipping centers, in the manufacturing of paper, in the
motion picture industry,in coal mining,in meat packing,
railroading, ship building—in fact, in every branch of
human activity can be found progress and profits
traceable directly to the pioneering of Westinghouse
Engineers.
